reviewText: It's worth the money. If you have on demand it's free. It is a great series. I recommend watching it

Say what you will, it is a good depiction of the War of the Roses, and, most importantly, it is historically accurate, as opposed to "The Other Boleyn Girl" and the first installment of "The Tudors". Also, as opposed to the just mentioned movies, the casting is excellent. Elizabeth Woodville is beautiful, King Edward IV is tall, Richard III is short with dark hair, the Duke of Clarence is good looking and greedy, etc., and David Oakes does a fantastic job playing the latter character. The one miscast person so far, in my opinion, is the young Prince of Wales who gets killed at Tewkesbury.
The witchcraft thing is definitely overdone, even more so than in the first 3 books of the series. According to history, Jaqcuetta Woodville was accused of witchcraft twice, and had to defend herself against the accusations. She must have done so ably, as she was never convicted and died of an unspecified disease when she was in her late 50's.
I wished there had been more outdoor shots, as in The Tudors, which had beautiful outdoor scenery and lighting. Here, it seems various people ride through the same woods constantly, or towards the same castle. But that is the only beef I have. If you like the War of the Roses, you will enjoy this series. I do and I will buy it once it becomes available for purchase.

I am addicted! After I viewed the first episode, I read everything I could find on the internet about Edward IV and Elizabeth.  I also ordered all three of Philippa Gregory's books in the series.  I have never been a history buff but the story of the War of the Roses is amazing!

Being an novice student of British history, I am always eager when any new show comes out relating to this topic.  While this is historical fiction it does follow history quite accurately.  The casting is phenomenal!  I will address some of the characters that really stood out for me.  I am NO authority these are just my opinions! :-)

Rebecca Ferguson portrays a brave and beautiful Queen Elizabeth.  Her performance is commanding and powerful.  She really portrays the strength and courage of her character during a very dangerous time in British history.

Amanda Hale presents viewers with a pious and scheming Lady Beaufort.  She does an excellent job of conveying her love for God and her son while showing the ugly side of greed and bad behavior.

Aneurin Barnard plays Richard Duke of Gloucester.  His character evolves from one that seems sweet and caring as the Duke however, when he becomes King Richard we see him transform  into power hungry and vile creature.

Max Irons as King Edward....I'm not sure about the casting with this actor.  While he does a good job acting, I don't feel that he physically fits the part.  Don't get me wrong he is very handsome he just doesn't fit the appearance of a King during the 1400's.  The portrayal of King Edward is one of a womanizer (which he was) but his real character was much richer than this.  I would have liked to see this developed more in the script.

David Oakes as George Duke of Clarence....PERFECT casting!  I can't see any other actor doing a better job!  He plays the jealous, conniving, backstabbing younger brother of King Edward with such conviction.

Janet McTeer as Jacquetta Woodville mother to Queen Elizabeth.  McTeer plays the mother figure with style and grace, portraying a character that is determined to see her daughter and family succeed.  The love that she has for her daughter is very palpable.

James Frain as Lord Warwick....James Frain, enough said. A great period actor; he never disappoints.  His portrayal of Warwick is thoughtful and insightful.

If you are looking for a juicy story filled with murder, scandal, backstabbing, and scheming....there is nothing like a story that really happened.  I recommend you give this show a try. ;-)

The White Queen is a ten-part mini-series based on three novels from Philippa Gregory's Cousins' War series: The White Queen, The Red Queen and The Kingmaker's Daughter. Unusually for this sort of series, the focus is less on the men and battles and more on the viewpoints and experiences of three women who played important roles in the period. These are Elizabeth Woodville, the minor noble who becomes Queen Consort (unusual in a time when the king usually marries European royalty or nobility); the pious Margaret Beaufort, the mother of Henry Tudor (the future Henry VII); and Anne Neville, the younger daughter of Richard Neville and the future wife of the notorious Richard III. Other women also play important secondary roles, such as Margaret of York (Henry VII's bride-to-be), Isabel Neville (Anne's older sister) and Jacquetta, Lady Rivers (Elizabeth Woodville's mother). This presents an interesting female perspective on a period of history traditionally dominated by accounts of battles and manly men strapping on armour.

Or rather, it would if the series worked. The White Queen may be the very definition of 'inconsistent'. The series lurches from mediocrity to being outright terrible to having a couple of pretty decent episodes and then back again. It's certainly no Game of Thrones (the huge success of which is almost certainly responsible for this series being made; the Wars of the Roses were a major influence on George R.R. Martin's books) but it often struggles to even be The Tudors.

On the plus side, the casting for the most part is good. The actresses playing the central three roles are all pretty good, though Amanda Hale's Margaret Beaufort has to cope with some pretty awful writing at times (her reaction to any crisis being to proclaim, "This is God's will!"), with Faye Marsay (Anne Neville) being one of the few actors to convincingly age in her performance as well as appearance over the course of the series. James Frain's scheming Earl of Warwick is excellent, with his political machinations occasionally being interrupted by Gordon Ramsay-style explosive losses of temper at his allies' incompetence or bad judgement. Rupert Graves schemes admirably as William, Lord Stanley in the latter half of the series (and should be signed up for Game of Thrones as soon as an appropriate role becomes available). Aneurin Barnard makes for a convincing Richard III, who is here played as a more tragic figure doomed by circumstance rather than a cartoon villain (despite developing a passing resemblance to Edward Scissorhands by the series finale). David Oakes (George, Duke of Clarence) may be getting typecast as 'gittish medieval noble bloke', having played this role before on Pillars of the Earth and The Borgias, but he plays it very well. The weakest link here is Max Irons, whose oafish and dull Edward IV is lacking the charisma of the real historical figure.

The series is at its best when centred on a short time-period. The sixth through eighth episodes (covering the relatively peaceful period between the Battle of Tewkesbury and Edward IV's death) are the strongest, as they focus on political machinations, family relationships and the characters themselves. The ninth episode, which jumps forward to the rise of Richard III and the situation with the Princes in the Tower, is also decent. However, the first half of the series is deeply flawed. Dialogue is almost exclusively based on exposition, with people reeling off information as if from a Wikipedia entry in a vain effort to keep the viewer up to speed on what the heck is going on. Weeks and sometimes months pass between scenes with absolutely no indication of the passage of time and the compression of seven years of fairly intricate history into just five episodes (the remaining five cover fourteen years) turns out to be a really bad idea. People swap sides, often for no apparent reason, and there is a lack of depth to events. It feels like the drama bits of a good docu-drama, only without the context for what is happening (a familiarity with the Wars of the Roses - or just keeping the Wikipedia page open as you watch - is useful). These early episodes are kept alive only by the heroic efforts of James Frain and, to a lesser extent, our three leads.

That said, the series finale is pretty diabolical. The lead-up to the Battle of Bosworth and the battle itself are compressed into one hour, leaving no time for the aftermath, some of which is deliciously ironic (particularly the taught relationships between Margaret Beaufort, Elizabeth Woodville and Maragret of York). The series has no real ending, just fading out after the battle without much reflection on what's happened. This feels anti-climactic and fails to put the series in its proper historical context for those who are not already knowledgeable about the time period. My co-watchers had no idea that Elizabeth Woodville and Margaret Beaufort were the grandmothers of Henry VIII, for example, and not ending with an epilogue where Margaret sees her grandson being crowned (she died only after Henry VIII came to power) seems like a missed opportunity.

In terms of historical accuracy, the series is surprisingly good in its first few episodes. It doesn't dial back the complexity of affairs too much, although a few minor characters like the Earl of Warwick's brother, are missing. As the series goes on, however, it deviates more and more from actual history. A few times it shows some good judgement - such as managing to maintain the ambiguity of the fate of the Princes in the Tower without sacrificing the drama - but more often than not it makes baffling choices. The showdown between Elizabeth Woodville's brother Antony, guarding her son and heir Edward V, and the soon-to-be Richard III is ripe stuff for television drama but the TV show simply removes it.

However, the series ultimately has two major problems which moves it from 'watchable tosh' to 'barely watchable hokum' category. The first is that Jacquetta and her daughter Elizabeth are witches. I don't meant they are accused of being witches (as both were in real life), but they actually are witches. They use magic on multiple occasions to summon storms to smash enemy fleets or delay them from sailing and put curses on people that ultimately kill them or leave their children dead. For a series based on real historical events, this injection of pure fantasy is jaw-droppingly stupid. They don't even sell it particularly well, with the participants discussing their magic-using ways in letters and everyone around them being relaxed about it.

Secondly, the show looks cheap. It may have been made for $25 million (that's about $39 million, or a bit more than half the budget of a season of Game of Thrones), but that's simply far too little to tell a story of this magnitude. The costumes are good (blatantly visible zips aside) but the bulk of the action takes place on a relatively small number of sets or on locations re-used a few too many times for supposedly different locations. The budget problem is most notable when it comes to the battles. The Wars of the Roses turned on a series of major battles at Towton, Barnet, Tewkesbury and Bosworth Field. Towton predates the start of the series, but the other three battles are fought during it and all of them are fake, unconvincing and so poorly-staged they might as well have not bothered. In particular, the decision to film both the Battle of Barnet and the Battle of Bosworth Field (and that's 'Field', remember) in the same forest (!) is truly moronic. Armies are shown marching in single file and then rushing towards one another with zero semblance of formation, tactics or strategy. The production team only seem to have about 15 extras available and no CGI budget (a couple of shots of ships aside, there doesn't seem to be any CGI at all in the series, which is baffling as it means they can't stage any big events convincingly), so the battles then unfold in extreme close-up with no continuity from shot to shot, making it almost impossible to follow what's going on. So as to avoid showing the fact they have no extras, the director also sticks the camera on the ground aiming up at people, which gets distracting quite quickly.

Ultimately, you cannot tell the story of 20 years of the Wars of the Roses (and not even the full conflict) in just ten episodes. The pacing is shot to hell in the first half of the series, meaning most people won't stick around for the decent-ish episodes in the latter half. The budget is woefully inadequate for the scale and scope of the series, and the attempt to stretch it to cover everything leaves it looking cheap. The writing is often excruciating (though this also improves in the latter half). All of this undermines the work of some pretty good actors heroically tackling the iffy material.

The White Queen (**) has moments when it almost works, but these moments can't quite make up for the crushing mediocrity and outright incompetence of the rest of the series.

Before I saw this series, I did not know what The White Queen was about. I saw a trailer for it on TV and found that it was to be a TV series based on Philippa Gregory's novel of the same name. I knew of her work from the movie version of her novel The Other Boleyn Girl (a very inaccurate take on Tudor history), but have not as of yet read any of her novels based roughly upon between 15-1600's on the Tudor's and so fourth. I love Tudor history and more than that I love anything on the British Monarchy. I know a lot on Henry VIII and his wives as well as Queen Elizabeth I, but I did not have any knowledge onto the Plantagenet's or anything about the War of the Roses. So I jumped on this series and immediately began to watch it hoping it to be better than the Showtime series The Tudors.

I have to say at first I wasn't sure I thought though while the story seemed to be intriguing, I wasn't falling for the main characters like King Edward and his wife Elizabeth in the first episode, but by the second and third episode of the series I was completely hooked. I know there are a lot of reviews from critics saying the series didn't hold up to the standards they expected, but I think a lot of that was based on the first episode alone in the series and not the story all together as a whole.

I never realized how fascinating the War of the Roses was or what it was about. I think what makes this story so much more compelling to me versus other shows around the time period like The Tudors, is that it is told in the view of the woman who stood behind the throne and who shaped England's history dramatically without the world even realizing their importance to what was happening on the throne and how they could influence it. Unlike in The Tudors where it was more of a mans view on the world. Their are three main woman who shape the story over the period of ten episodes. You have the White Queen Elizabeth who was King Edwards wife, then you have Queen Anne who was Queen to King Richard III and you have Margaret who becomes the King's mother to Henry VII.

These woman are each inspiring in their own ways. Elizabeth Woodhouse is a very strong character in the story. She's not afraid to voice her opinion and stand for what she says. She was also one of the first monarch's to have her children stay with her while they were growing up, where in all other noble families you would send them away for months or years at a time to be tutored and not brought back to live with their families till after their education was completed on how they were to behave as a future king or queen. While Anne in the beginning is very passive wanting to please her family and sister, she is caught in the middle as her father tries to get her older sister married to one of the brother's of Kind Edward and keeps being tossed aside till her father needs her in one of his schemes to take the throne. Through all of this she finds her strength and takes charge of her own destiny. While Margaret is devote to god and seeing her son put on the throne at such huge odds that when you think of it, it's amazing she achieved so much with so much in front of her, when the cards seemed stacked against her.

What makes this series work so well are the different view points that are captured through the eyes of these woman. You can't help but feel for each one of them as they are pushed from one place to another, but each time this happens they rise again. What Philippa Gregory has done so well is she has shown 3 different view points of the same conflict and has shown us as the viewers different perspectives to the story line based on view you are looking at.

This series is a fast pace series as far as time lapses go. Episode 1 starts off with the meeting and marrying of King Edward to Elizabeth Woodhouse. By episode two they are married and have children and by the end you are at the beginning of the Tudor era. Even though there are gaps by years in the show it flows so well together and the drama keeps you glued to the screen. You can't help but feel for these ladies in the show.

As far as how accurate this series it to her books I don't know, how accurate it is to history I do not know either. What makes a great historical drama period piece is when a author knows how to weave the fiction on around the historical events that truly took place. I feel that as far as I can see Gregory has done just that, but just don't quote me completely on it! The magic of an author should be to captivate the audience and have have them wondering which parts are the fictitious and which are reality and when it comes to Plantagenet's history it can be hard to say what was fact and what was Tudor propaganda. Leading the reader or watcher to make up their own mind. Which is exactly what Philippa Gregory does.

I fell in love with this series the first episode, I think it was very well written I am going to buy the series.
 the above reviews tell you the story, so I won't bore you with more.

One night early there was a preview showing of this new series from the Brits. It looks promising if a bit unorthodox in its approach to history and slips in the settings and costumes. The series is based on Philippa Gregory's novel, `The Cousins' War' and roughly the story line promises to follow these lines:  Set against the backdrop of the Wars of the Roses, the series is the story of the women caught up in the long-drawn-out conflict for the throne of England. It starts in 1464--the nation has been at war for nine years fighting over who is the rightful King of England, as two sides of the same family, the House of York and the House of Lancaster, are in violent conflict over the throne. The story focuses on three women in their quest for power, as they manipulate behind the scenes of history--Elizabeth Woodville, Margaret Beaufort and Anne Neville.

In the first episode we don't see much more than King Edward's bedding and wedding of Elizabeth, a lot of bickering, some fighting, and some castle intrigue. Rebecca Ferguson plays Queen Elizabeth, Amanda Hale plays Lady Margaret Beaufort, Faye Marsay is Anne Neville, and the remarkable actors are Janet McTeer as Jacquetta Woodville (Elizabeth's magical mum) and Max Irons (handsome son of Jeremy Irons) as King Edward. James Frain is an unusually grumpy and sour Lord Warwick and Caroline Goodall is splendid as the evil Duchess Cicely. It is difficult to tell from an isolated episode, but the series has enough interest in the poorly understood realm of the War of the Roses for American audience that it will probably have staying power. Stay tuned...Grady Harp, August 13

there is a way to watch bbc as it plays in England, and so i have seen parts 1-8.  two more to go.  i have not been this pleased by a docu drama in a long time, and this one is right up there with the tudors.  the writer is a history teacher at one of the prestigious colleges in uk, and she writes with passion and accuracy.  its about the cousins war, or war of the roses.  The writer concentrates not on the men involved but the 3 women behind the scene.  The costumes are documented, and the buildings are historical.  the women are powerful, clever, driven, and with elizabeth, in love. its about protecting their right to the throne, and they do it vengeance and devotion to their cause and families.  it is rich in colour, and i was wishing there was 15 parts, not 10!  if you liked the tudors, you will love this, minus some of the fun but sometimes brutal sex scenes. there were a couple but tastefully done, the concentration being on family pride.
enjoy!

OMG This is supposed to pass as history....
Nothing in this series rings true, Every thing seems to be 21st century pasted on to 14th century backgrounds.
Not only  the zippers which others have commented on, but some of the dresses and costumes that they have their characters don, are Edwardian and not 14th century. The speech and  the mannerisms of the characters are distinctly modern
Can one  just imagine a 15th century King addressed thus by a nobleman:" King Henry, Sit down there" I mean really, who wrote these dialogues and then there were the princesses screaming "Daddy" when Edward IV returns. Admittedly none of us were witnesses, but I do think that is distinctly a modern form of address for a father.  I realize that Edward and Warwick were cousins/comrades with a long history behind them but once Edward became an anointed king the equation would have changed. I cannot believe that the King would have called  Neville "Warwick" but Richard Neville calls Edward by his first name!!!! The list goes on and on,
 Margaret of Anjou speaks English with a perfect British accent.... but ironically the character reminds us, " I am French"

Finally will someone tell Amanda Hale that repeated grimaces can only go so far to be construed as genuine acting ability. Lady Margaret Beaufort's character was annoying  to the point of making my skin crawl.
Gratuitous nudity has already been addressed by others and so I will leave it alone

A handful of uninteresting female characters become the main players and then many scenes are about women crying or screaming women giving birth. Women and babies. If thats what you want to watch this series is for you. The series suffers from poor lighting and camera use. Did they hire a bunch of students to make this?

I love good miniseries like Band of Brothers (2001), Frank Herberts Dune (2000), Into the West (2005), Lonesome Dove (1989, Pride and Prejudice (1995), Taken (2002) and The 10th Kingdom (2000) because they have beginnings, middles and endings, like a good novel.

Here are a few series I really enjoyed watching more than once: Band of Brothers (2001), Battlestar Galactica (2004-2009), Black Sails (2014-2017), Cowboy Bebop (1998), Downton Abbey (2010-2015), Firefly (2002), Game of Thrones (2011-2019), The IT Crowd (2006-2013), Jericho (2006-2008), Lonesome Dove (1989), Lost (2004-2010), Merlin (2008-2012), Pride and Prejudice (1995), Rome (2005-2007), Spartacus: Gods of the Arena (2011), Stargate: SG-1 (1997-2007), Stargate: Atlantis (2004-2009), Star Trek The Original Series (1966-1969) and Star Trek Voyager (1995-2001). The first thing we must say, from my American frame of reference, is that this has nothing to do with race. This epics the Wars of the Roses -- one rose white, one red. Specifically, this series epics the reign of King Edward IV and his consort Queen Elizabeth. They are Yorks, the white rose. And, oh my goodness, what brilliant cast, each artistically depicted from the physical appearances to the garments they wore to the sets to the props and even the lighting. I literally cannot think of a mediocre actor or scene in the series.  The tale itself is so filled with intrigue that one need not fabricate, yet it takes a poetic license with detail. I was happy to see that Richard was not portrayed from a Shakespearian point of view -- which is usually the case. Again, from my American point of view, I could have found it every bit as delicious without all of the lurid sex scenes. Can nothing be left to the imagination? Ugh. Fortunately, I could fast forward through more of that, and still find it utterly delicious. This is the first series I've ever binged-watched in my life, but I just couldn't tear myself away...  I will ALWAYS wish that Henry Tutor didn't prevail, even though he did eventually give us Elizabeth I, but Henry Tutor did prevail. If only the little boys in the tower had been better protected. Sigh.
This series was exciting every step of the way. It was easy to follow and I enjoyed it very much.

I really loved this series. From the script, to the excellent performances, to the lavish sets, it's full of period detail and technical merit. As an amateur medievalist, I was very familiar with the story, and the series sticks very close to fact as we know it, while giving a nod to the book on which this is based. Elizabeth was a fascinating, smart, engaging woman in real life (and reportedly quite a beauty) who well understood what she had to do in order for she and her family to survive in a tough society and era.  The ad sells this as a story about "scheming" women - I find that really cheap and insulting, and frankly that isn't what the story is about. These women had enormous heart, did have morals, and also had the brains to play the games they were forced to play from birth.  That isn't "scheming and manipulation", it's survival.  I want to mention especially the beautiful performance of Rebecca Ferguson in the lead role - this series garnered her some well-deserved and overdue professional attention and led to other roles.  The viewer will recognize the actress playing Warwick's older daughter as the woman playing a lead role in Poldark. And Max Irons is really fine - and great to look at - as the tempestuous, strong-willed warrior king Edward IV - the real man was as tall, as handsome, as stubborn, as impetuous, and  Max nails it. Edward is remembered as one of England's most successful kings.  Anyone who loves history, wants to understand the Wars of the Roses, and great historical drama, will like this one.
Entertaining, and addicting but not much character development. I didn't feel invested in anyone but the main protagonist. Many scenes felt too staged and not very authentic.

This is without a doubt a good, entertaining show that kept its entertaining qualities throughout the story. You can always know a good show by how many episodes actually hold your attention. This show definitely did that! The only reason why I didn't give it 5 stars was because after awhile I grew a bit weary of all of the underhanded dealings and the selfish ambitions of every character in the show. If people being back-stabby is not your thing, I would soooo stay away from this show. If you like decent writing, great actors, historical pieces, and a bit of treachery than I highly recommend this show.

I LOVED this series!!! First let me tell those who are still watching for the next season; It is called THE WHITE PRINCESS. You start out with Elizabeth Woodville, then the next season is her daughter Elizabeth of York (Plantagenet).
I watched the first season. Later while I was working on my family tree I found out that these people are my ancestors.
Needless to say I had to watch it again.

I also purchased the paperback books and Audible books from the entire series. I am intrigued. :-)
Brilliant mini series! Really wish they had continued with a second season, and so forth!

With a sustained effort over a two year period, I made it through this series. It is soap opera history, complete with bits of ridiculous magic, tragic and opportunistic loves, and constant driving greed and lust as motivation. I can't say there was a plot or any story line, just a bunch of pretty scenes with a lot of undeveloped characters strung together in a vague historical chronology. The female characters are more interesting, with the religious zealot who interprets every advantage as god's will, and, toward, the end, the smug snooty teenager who figures she's going to be queen whoever wins. You won't feel anything for any of the characters, and you won't learn anything about history or human motivations, other than everybody wants to be king or get with the king.

1 star because the series is completely without the need for. frequent, prolonged, nude  sex scenes.  Frequent witchcraft scenes that may not hold true to historical events. Using FIVE WATT BULBS IN EVERY SINGLE SCENE INDOORS  so that people or rooms CAN'T be seen.  WHY a movie maker doesn't want you to see throughout an entire movie is beyond acceptable and is annoying and irredeemable.  ALL the talking and scheming cannot be true, only guessed at so I don't find this "historical".  As per a series goes, there was far too much talking in order to stretch the series into boredom in far too many scenes. Lady Margaret, and her, far too many scenes that consisted of twisted, rubbery, contorted facial expressions got on my nerves.  She wins the brass ring for letting the world see on the outside what her inner thoughts were of hate, malice, deceit, self-righteousness, greed, pretension, self-gain, devious, fraudulent,..I'll just say "evil".  The entire series is, in essence, how man goes through life without God, has made themselves their own gods, their blindness and deafness toward the true purpose of why God created them, lives spent in greed, power, deceit, fear, satanism, and sex, self adornment and self adulation.  The world calls it "the elite" or "the Royals", or King's and Queens, or godless human race.  God calls them "the Spiritually dead".

Now the Cousins War/War of the Roses in history is one heck of a blood bath! I mean full-tilt boogie insane on how they operated and waged war over the throne. This is another concoction based off of Phillipa Gregory - she does historical fantasy fiction; so these are real time periods and people (some a amalgamation of the historic persons) . It is pretty decent as far as that goes (it was basically gossip that Richard lll was in love with his niece Elizabeth - they weren't going to marry - I don't know of any Papal dispensation that would ok that! That didn't deter a lot of actual historic marriages/relations in the past---- uhhh..) I digress Max Irons (son of Jeremy Irons) is Edward VI and Rebecca Ferguson is Elizabeth Woodville. James Frain - a mainstay in these types of series (he plays such a good baddie!) is Earl of Warwick - The Kingmaker, Janet McTeer is Jacquetta Woodville - Elizabeth's mother. They rely heavily on the hearsay that she was a descendant of Melusina a river witch/goddess. STILL it is good - I wouldn't let the young ones watch - I mean it isn't a PBS/BBC documentary with historic facts and historians and professors talking about it - it is actors and nudity and violence - they do not show the actual beheadings but do show plenty and I do mean plenty of the birthday suits. It really isn't that bad - I mean the entire series is entertaining and the cast is lovely.

I just binge watched season 1.  It is riveting.  The costumes are splendid.  The acting superb.  It is a must for anglophiles and anyone who loves historical fiction.  Though I cannot vouch for the accuracy of the history, you definitely get the jest of the time period and brutality of political maneuvering of the times.  The series certainly portrays the fragile nature of the life of anyone who sat on the throne or who was in line to ascend to the throne of any country. There seemed to be little loyalty within families when it came to who would or would not ascend to the throne.

I've read some reviews which describe it as porn, so I would like to address that allegation.  It is not porn and anyone who calls it that has not seen porn.  There is implied sex but in my opinion, it is done tastefully.  There is some nudity, no genitals.  Some people may have found distasteful the fact that there were teenage girls being forced (by their parents) to marry for political posturing.  In the historical context, I did not consider it to be rape when a girl was forced to wed and then have sex.  She knew she was expected to produce a male heir and would have to have sex to do so.  Women were subjugated and their lives dependent on the wishes of their father or husband. Arranged marriages, especially among the nobility, was common.  Marriage was a contract between families to gain status, money or position; and male heirs were the goal of those unions.  Social norms regarding marriage and children were much different in those times than they are now and you must keep that in mind and not judge based on what would be accepted today.  So if any of that bothers you, this might not be the series for you.

While in the broad strokes of history, the series is fairly accurate, it is overly romanticized, the witchcraft element is screwball, the accuracy of the costumes atrocious (some of the fabrics are visibly synthetic, some of the jewelry looks play jewelry from Walmart, few of the women wear headdresses and when they do, they are comically and cheaply rendered), and the palace flooring and carpets are so modern, cheap, shiny, and new, they look as thought they are fresh out of Home Depot.  The period and the characters are interesting and deserve more intelligent treatment.

Five RUTHLESS Stars. This is Season 1 of "The White Queen", based on the "Cousin's War" series of novels by talented author Phillipa Gregory: "The White Queen", "The Red Queen", and "The Kingmaker's Daughter". With much assumed dramatic license, in this historical recreation of events involving the "War of the Roses", it's king versus would-be king, relatives versus relatives, house versus house versus house, commoners versus noble lineage, army versus army, spy versus spy, some seeming mysticism, and 3 very determined, ruthless females pulling the strings in the foreground and background to get or keep one of the biggest royal prizes of them all: the English throne. It's fascinating to watch the aging of the characters as the plot develops, sometimes involving multiple actors, as they age.

"The White Queen" begins in 1464, during the "War of the Roses", the reign of King Edward IV, and the entanglements of the York and Lancaster families. The storyline builds steadily towards the climatic battle events and the aftermath of Episode 10, as things come to a head and all of the stops are pulled out. Some historical mysteries that remain to this day are hinted at during the show. Starring an outstanding group of actors, including Rebecca Ferguson, Max Irons, Janet McTeer, Aneurin Barnard, Amanda Hale, Rupert Graves, Faye Marsay, Ben Lamb, Freya Mavor, Tom McKay, James Frain, Shaun Dooley, Nicholas Croucher, Sonny Ashbourne Serkis, Andrew Gower, and more. Highly Recommended. Five RIVETING Stars.  (Starz Originals. BBC. A Company Pictures Production, Playground Entertainment. Rated TV-MA. Color. HD. CC. X-Ray. Time-10 episodes of about 1 hour each.)

I have always found the War of the Roses saga massively confusing.  Watching this series made it a lot clearer to me.  I wish that the conspiracy theory of Elizabeth coughing up a kid who looks like a Prince to go to the Tower to join his brother hadnt been done.  The theory is just so hard to believe that, in a way, it cheapened the story and really if you bring up that theory, where are you going to go with it besides nowhere?  And not only could the writer/s go nowhere with it, they hit a dead end made of brick and mortar and were probably hoping the viewer wouldnt notice.  If it weren't for this, I would have given 5 stars.

On the other side of the coin is the Margaret Tudor (Stanley).  What a remarkable woman and such faith to see her son through.  I wish I could have better understood why nobody bothered to kill off Henry.  They had no problem killing off other people and, as it was stated when considering the murder of the Princes, boys grow into men.  This theory never spread to Henry fortunately but again, it was never clear why it did not.

Lastly, I patiently waited a few years for this series to get on Prime.  It was worth the wait and although I know it was done as advertisement for The White Princess that begins filming this year, Im not sure I will wait five years for the Princess to come on Prime and I sure as hell won't pay for it.

This is a delicious series based on Philippa Gregory's historical novels about the Wars of the Roses  in 15th Century England. The name of the series derives from the House of York's emblem of the white rose. The Yorks warred for decades with the House of Lancaster, represented by the emblem of the Red rose. The characters in this very real slice of history are riveting, notwithstanding the perspective of over 500 years. I was impressed by the acting chops of all of the actors who portrayed characters great and small in this series.
The era in which this drama is set is one of the most confusing historically of any in English history. It would be helpful for any viewer to read, at a minimum, Philippa Gregory's books before watching the series, lest the intricacies of the conflict between the Yorks and the Lancasters cause the viewer to lose track of the plot. It is well worth the effort, however. The era of the Wars of the Roses was the mother of all soap operas.
One final note: it is not suitable for children.

If you really want to hear the story of the Game of Thrones there is no better dynasty to study than the Plantagenets.  They have it all, villians, heroes, great warriors, and cowards.  Most of history portrays Elizabeth as a vixen who plotted to capture a kings heart.  Edward the IV is presented as a great king who died too soon whose only failing was a failure to control his appetite.  A totally Plantagenet failing.  The name King Richard has only appeared three times in English history.  The first Richard was the closest thing to a God of War as Europe ever came.  He was better as Richard the Lion Hearted.  The second Richard was partly to blame for the beginning of the War of the Roses.  His Uncle, John of Gaunt Duke of Lancaster had stayed loyal to his nephew after the death of the Black Prince.  When the Duke died Richard had banished his son, Henry of Bolingbroke, and attempted to seize all the Lancaster land.  Henry became the IV, his son the glorious Henry the V, and his son was the wobbly Henry the VI who fell to Edward the IV.  Oh, and Henry's claim to the throne?  Came from his Mother Margaret of Beaufort the great-granddaughter of John of Gaunt and his third wife Katherine Swynford with whom he had an affair for over 20 years.  The Tudor's can thank John of Gaunt for managing to twist both the arm of King Richard the II and the Pope to sign off on legitimizing his children by Katherine Swynford upon their marriage and failing to add the clause that would have blocked them from claiming the throne.
The White Queen is just an approach to the end of the story from a different point of view than what is usually told.  Usually, Richard is presented as an evil man who killed to innocent boys.  But of all the actors in this drama Richard the III had the least reason to kill the boys and Henry the most.  We will never know.

Ok, like the Tudors, this is a story within a political context.  Part fact, part fiction, pure entertainment.  Romanticized?  Yes, but it doesn't drip with sappy women whose only desire is to promote the men in their lives.  They are presented as complex, multifaceted people with varying abilities and interests; some are selfless, others as are as selfish as any male political animal.  It is for this reason that I can groan through the inaccurate, even fanciful historical contrivances and just enjoy the story as a telling from the feminine perspective.

12/4/2016 - Like most modern historical novelists, Gregory takes a lot of liberty with the real history.  Elizabeth never slept with her Uncle Richard.  Her marriage to Henry Tudor was a gloriously happy one and their many children were intelligent, charming, gifted and religious devout.  There were other instances where the historical facts were distorted, but this was a very entertaining series.  All the nuances, political, religious, social, gender, were touched upon in this series.  Excellent scripts and very good acting for the most part.

This is a startling piece of historical fiction, bringing to attention the lengths to which humankind will go to achieve wealth, fame, power.
Betrayed loyalties, schemes, traps, wars, threats, violence, cruelty, long-standing hatreds, envy, hostility - along with equally passionate experiences at the other end of the emotional scale - are quite normal here as the Aengles and the Saxons war for the monarchy and the perpetuation of their name.

There is lots of talking, mostly to explain the speaker's understanding of his/her motives, the complicated history behind the acquisitions and takings of the throne, and the machinations of the human heart. Bloody business - and very good drama.

Boy, can Rebecca Ferguson take a tight close up, freckles and all. She's incredibly disciplined. Knows her angles and displays strength and elegance in every scene. She's playing against some other incredible actors. Amanda Hale, who plays Lady Margaret Beaufort, is Rebecca's nemesis, one of several in the series. Whereas the production budget for a similar series, Vikings was estimated to be around $40,000,000, the production budget for The White Queen came in at around $27,000,000 USD. As far as spectacle goes, The White Queen can't be compared to Vikings in terms of scope and scale. What makes The White Queen Work, I think, are two key elements. The first is Rebecca Ferguson. The second is the set locations in Ghent and Bruges, medieval appearing cities. There's material in this series that would be a hard "R" rating, so be careful.

At first, I was very excited by this series, especially when the first few scenes didn't have excessive violence. However, this series has far too much nudity. I prefer shows with no nudity at all, but this show had nudity at such unnecessary times, it was riduculous. I kept laughing at the show because it was so absurd, like someone randomly talking about how they bought their shoes at Payless in the middle of an episode. Its so out of place that its comical. We can tell a character is a prostitute without seeing breasts. We can tell people are having sex without seeing breasts. We can tell that a couple is passionately in love without seeing breasts. We can tell someone is having a bath without seeing breasts. It really felt like breasts were one of the main characters of this show! If you would like an interesting period drama without nudity try Poldark. Really great, thrilling period drama! Other great period shows include Downtown Abbey, Dr. Thorne, and Jane Austen movies, though these have far less action than Poldark. This series could have been much better.

Great show! I loved it! The series is set against the backdrop of the Wars of the Roses and presents the story of the women involved in the protracted conflict for the throne of England. It starts in 1464; the nation has been at war for nine years fighting over who is the rightful King of England, as two sides of the same family, the House of York and the House of Lancaster, are in violent conflict over the throne. The story focuses on three women in their quest for power, as they manipulate events behind the scenes of history: Elizabeth Woodville, Margaret Beaufort, and Anne Neville. Elizabeth Woodville is the central character in the novel The White Queen, while Margaret Beaufort and Anne Neville are the focus of the novels The Red Queen and The Kingmaker's Daughter, respectively. However, all three characters appear in all three novels that went to make up the television series. Now I am looking forward for the sequel : The White Princess

Based on novel of storyline of English medieval Wars of Roses between houses of York (banner White Rose) vs. Lancaster (later adopts banner Red Rose) and factions who fight for the crown while 'the kingmaker' Earl of Warwick' attempts to manipulate all sides and more. The program is full of royal court drama, intrigue, historical fiction and offers good cinematography and performances that includes well choreographed battle scenes.
Overall not bad.  Costuming had minor errors.  Nice historical fiction.

If you liked the Tudors, you will like this.  It is an historical drama about Edward IV and his bride Elizabeth Woodville and the trials and tribulations of being king & queen of England.  It starts 9 years into the War of the Roses and continues for about 20 years to tell their story.  Edward's brother becomes Richard III (whose bones were found under a parking lot in England a few years ago).  It is a fun story line to watch, while telling the story of an actual English king.  There is lots of drama thrown in, so it can be a little soap opera-like but that is what makes it more fun than reading a history book.  I would recommend this series.

The White Queen is a must see  people who enjoy reading  about English history, specifically about the war of the roses era. It's told from the females' perspective. Janet McTeer does a wonderful job playing queen Elizabeth's mother. Her character is a strong woman with a gentle soul. Amanda Hale's character, Margaret Beaufort, is annoyingly obsessive about her son becoming king. Ms. Hale did an excellent job portraying her. Though the show did take a bit of liberty telling the story of these women's lives, I think it did a great job overall!

This mini series is historically accurate for the timeframe it covers; 1470 or so, England.  It helps bring into perspective the corruption that power brings, and what some people will do for it.  The writers took some creative license, and no one can be sure what really happened outside of what has been preserved through writings and records of that timeframe.  The only character I found completely annoying was the mother of Henry Tudor.  She was playing the part of a pious woman, but constantly made everything about herself.  Perhaps that was in the writings and the actress strove to portray her accurately.  But in any case, it was annoying.  But not so much as to make me give this nothing less than 5 stars.  This series ends with Henry Tudor taking the throne.  The show, "The Tudors", which some may be familiar with, happens a couple generations later and picks up there.  History is important, and this series was done well.  There is some brief nudity, breasts, buttocks, perhaps an inappropriate hookup or two, but nothing too racy.

This series starts out well. Interesting story line, nice character development, fine acting, quality production.  Got us hooked enough to keep watching.  Good stuff all around.  But as the series approaches it climax, plot and story devolve into a jumbled mess.  Pacing becomes MUCH too quick. Things start happening so quickly that I found it difficult to keep characters and events straight.  It's as though the original intent was to create a multi-season series that got cancelled about 3/4 of the way into the first season, so the writers tried to cram absolutely everything into the last few episodes.  This really spoiled the overall impression of the series. Worth a look, for sure, but prepare for some frustration as you get deeper in.

The War of the Roses never fails to fascinate.  Men and women, equally blinded by greed and ambition, clash as they reach for the hollow victory of winning the crown.  Then their real troubles begin as they attempt to hold it against betrayal, the plots of other kings or queens and the ravages of disease and time.  It makes you wonder why the adjective 'noble' has a positive meaning?  In the context of this story, a noble gesture might involve a poisoned beverage.

Well scripted, well-acted,  Some factual (historical) issues, but when are there not in dramatizations of history. After all, this is a miniseries. Do not use this series as the basis for any masters' thesis in history.  Still, more accurate than the Shakespeare history plays (although you should still read/watch them, because, well, they're Shakespeare).  Basically watching this series is well worth the time.  Stick with it. Find a block of time when you can binge watch -- say over a rainy weekend or if you're in bed with a cold.  Seriously -- watching in one or two sittings is best. Interesting takes on Richard 3, as well as the young princes. It does truly show (as do the novels on which the series is based) how girls were used as pawns in manipulating political power for their fathers, husbands or brothers.  And for those women who were able to exert their own influence, what price they paid.  Have times changed?  Not sure.

Impelling drama that grabs hold in the beginning and doesn't let go. The romance between the key characters through time is both hot and emotionally true. The mother/daughter relationship is a study in what makes that relationship work. To have that mother and to be that mother are equally appealing. The vital Plantagenet history lesson is almost too much to take in. Mainly because the intricacies of these relationships are so humanely crafted and explored in depth that the universality takes you deep into your own relationships, greeds, longings, loves, missteps and wrong choices and you have to pause...and process for yourself. Meantime the story has moved on and it's hard to catch up to left brain facts. No worries. No problem watching this one again. And this time I might even notice whether or not the storyline totally adheres to the riveting book. Bottom line: Especially for anyone who hungers to be swooped into another world and captured there deliciously, this is superb marathoning!

Love. It.

 Getting completely caught up with Game of Thrones to the current wait for the next season was a little bit like quitting coffee, cigarettes, and red wine cold turkey,  simultaneously. (Which I have done, minus one of the three. I'm not @$?#ing quitting coffee.) Somehow, we discovered White Queen, and at least the tremors have stopped.

There are no flying dragons, it's true, but there are still lots of nude 'people' (R.F.) with perfect... well... everything, and oh yes, the writing is fantastic, the cinematography, astounding.

The quick and dirty: watch it.

Keep in mind that it's (fairly) history-based, so it requires that we think a little more than our iPhone overlords have trained us to, but I mean we've accepted Dinklage's accent for many years now, so come on, we can do this.  And coming away with a rough historical outline of the formation of England's monarchy and  the beginnings of the British Empire,  as opposed to having a great deal of knowledge about a land that doesn't really exist, can't possibly do us as much intellectual damage as we might initially think.

The first six episodes were good, with captioninng.  I need subtitles because I'm almost deaf.  However, for some reason, Amazon Prime chose to remove the captions, and I can't make any sense of the last four episodes.  I also went back to some of the episodes that were captioned when I watched the first time.  None of those are captioned either.  The Americans with Disability Act specifies that all entertainment (as well as other parts of life) should be accessible to all people--including those who have hearing loss.  The removal of captions from this series violates that act.  I'm disappointed that I can't watch the last four episodes, as it would be a waste of my time.  I'll go to venues in the future that honor my disability.

Generally speaking, historical fiction can be fun.  Some of it is even well done.  The Tudors, for example, never kept us guessing what would happen to Anne Boleyn, but the drama remained.  Here...eh... not so much.  This is the story of a bunch of back-biting, scheming, calculating women who, though they appear to possess brains are used much the way breeding stock is used (to produce offspring).  Their opinions or desires are not really important.  But that doesn't stop them from being scheming malevolent witches.  There are so many women who look alike that it's hard to keep the plots straight, and while we like King Eddie, Queen Betsy is a bit much to take.  Okay, I know you can tell this was posted by a man.  My wife likes this show, and that's why we watch it.  If you are a man (or identify with a man) then you likely will find this better than Melatonin.  On the other hand, if you are a woman, you may enjoy it.  I did not.

EXCELLLENT!!! ...and after much research I am even more excited that there is a sequel to this series as The White Princess being created for 2017 :) The 1st season, The  White Queen was so exciting, so engaging~ it had EVERYTHING, action, adventure, a bit of history from a very different perspective, conflict, romance...Definitely worth your time to watch :)

Note: This review is only based on the first 2 episodes

On the plus side, it does look pretty - the sets, the costumes, the actors, the camera work - it's all very nice, and the acting is good.

But the characters don't have much depth - even the main characters - so it gets pretty dull pretty quick. Good characters are smiling and pretty, bad ones are sneering and ugly, the family members, aside from the mother, are just basically props - even the sex and the witchcraft is kinda boring, which doesn't, I think, bode well for the rest of it, so I'm stopping.

Though if you're just looking for some fluffy middle-ages romance at the end of the day, definitely give this a shot. It's not bad, by any means; it's just not for me.

For people who love period pieces, this one is excellent. It is the thing the Brits do so welltell their own history. The White Queen covers the period from the end of the War of the Roses (1470s-1485) to the rise of the Tudors. It is filled with malice and Machiavellian cunning. Three women wish to be Queen. Elizabeth is a stunningly beautiful widow whose looks beguile the young king, Edward York. They marry without permission, and Elizabeth becomes queen. At the same time Margaret Beaufort connives to have her son, Henry Tudor, seated on the throne. She manages to accomplish this feat, but not without suffering. The third woman, Anne Neville, is perhaps the most evil. She whines, wheedles, and lies her way onto the throne. The acting is superb. The costumes and settings are excellent. The story moves at a quick pace. This is a show that is best for binge watching. There are many characters, and if you do not see the episodes close together, you will not be able to tell one male from another.

I am huge fan on British history up until the Stuart era and have been reading about Elizabeth Woodville and the Cousins Wars for years and the only thing that I can say that this show does accurately is give you a good idea of the timeline of how things came to be and the impact that all this war and fighting had on Elizabeth and her children.  I've always felt bad for her since because of this conflict she lost two brothers, her father, her first husband, three of her sons, and was forced to go through so much hardship.  This show gives you a good idea of how the women must have felt going through all this.
Having said that I will give some criticisms.  First, this show does a very poor job in showing the maneuvers of the English court and how many retainers the English royalty had.  Like theTudors did a good job of showing that at least.  Here it just looks like th actors are in medeival times.  Second, the thing where they have Cecily Duchess of York completely favoring George and then Richard has no real basis.  The part where she says I can make George king is based on a rumor and a statement one ambassador made at the time, that was probably false, because the Duchess was well known for being an extremely pious woman and would never have admitted to having had an affair.  Plus Edward is believed to have looked like the Duchess while Edward's brothers looked like his father (as in future Richard would attest that Edward was a bastard because he looked nothing like the former duke of York).  Though true that Duchess Cecily was opposed to the marriages it is widely believed that those feeligs dissipated in future since she ended up spending alot of time with the Queen in EdwardVI's reign.  She didn't even go to Richard III coronation, and mentioned neither of her younger sons in her will.  The only thing she mentioned was that she was honored by her son his majesty the kiNG eDWARDvi of England.
Thirdly, not that the Woodville's got what they came for, but they weren't as perfect as the show seemsto portray them.  They were too aggressive in placing their political influence, and made it very clear that they had no intention of letting Richard make decisions, effectlvely alienating him before Prince Edward was even crowned.  Also they did marry their 19 year old son, John (who gets executed in ep 2) to the 60 year old widow of the Duchess of Norfolk, since she had a large fortune at her death, ironically she even outlived him.  This gave them the reputation of money grabbing family, and there were instances where the father delibrately crushed people in his way.  Though Ill say that they were alot better than Warick who this show captured quite well.  He wanted to have power for himself through Edward and when Edward made it evident that he wasn't going to be pushed around Warick switched sides.  Also historians mostly see the Warick being pushed aside not because of Elizabeth Woodville's influence but because of Edward's desire to emphasis his power
Oh and Richard and Elizabeth. . .  No just no.  Even back then it was frowned upon for a niece to marry her uncle.  I mean why did they have to go that far I dunno.  Anne Neville in real life actually liked her nieces and recieved them in great favor, and Richard according to texts seems to have tried to make Henry tudor look stupid by having Elizabeth appear in court dressed lavishly in order to spread rumors that there was an intended wedding.  Richard needed the power of the people's opinion more than anything at the time since his son was dead and tUDOR was already getting alot of support.
I like this show since it gives u a rough idea of the politics of the time and gets people interested in teh period/  And i think this is an interesting era because it literally paved the way for the ideas and religious change that startedt o happen in England during Henry VIII era.  Elizabeth of York raised Henry to make him aware that women were capable thinkers and he recognized their power, although he asserted that males were better, he did recognize his daughters' right to inherit thr throne later.  So yeah this show is a good watch

I'm a big fan of Phillipa Gregory's books and this series was well done. It combines the stories of Anne Neville, Margaret Beaufort, and Elizabeth Grey. If you want to find out what happens with the story at the end of the series, you'll have to read the books "The White Princess" and "The King's Curse", also written by Gregory. The series itself was done as well as Showtime's Tudor series (also available on Amazon) with beautiful costumes, amazing castles and scenery, and of course, it has alot of racey scenes too. I watched the whole thing in one day. If you love English history as much as I do, this is a must have!!!

This is well written and acted with just enough grit to be interesting but not overwhelming with either sex or violence.  I keep fact checking with online histories of the Wars of the Roses, and it seems to be keeping to the facts with the main storyline.  The witch part adds some dimension too.  I really like it as a followup after finishing Game of Thrones this season.  And a great prequel to The Tudors.

This is a dramatization of the Wars of the Roses, which were fought over the throne of England in the 15th Century. It's told from a woman's point of view, specifically, that of Elizabeth Woodville, the "White Queen." The history of those wars rivals any romantic fantasy you can name, with love and betrayal, good and evil, and general greed for power played out against a legendary background. The writing is strong, the acting is excellent and the story follows the historical outline closely. Though violence is an essential part of the history of these times, there's not a lot of graphic violence depicted. There are tasteful (by today's standards)  sexual scenes. The romantic elements are given focus, though the other story elements are not neglected. The real Elizabeth  was accused of witchcraft during her reign and the series depicts her as actually practising the art at crucial points in the story. Most of these correspond to events the historical Elizabeth was accused over, so this is a fun element. I enjoyed the series immensely.

First the Middle Ages did not have zippers.
 They do have all of the people in the saga required to show how Richard III became England's king. Richard's body has been exhumed so it is clear that he did have a hunchback a very crooked back and these deformities were the strong motivation for his actions. Four queens vying for power and multiple noble houses clashing for the ultimate glory ... the crown of England, after the War of Roses. I personally could have done without some of the sex scenes but the characters stay true to form throughout, and the calculation, betrayals and ever present danger will keep you on the edge of your seat.

Some of the most unnerving moments occur as the women in one camp or another see their men ride off to battle and then wait ... sitting alone in a dimly lit room ... waiting for the returning rider with news that they are the new queen, or that all is lost (husband, land, access to their children, personal freedom and possibly their lives).  You feel it along with them.  Things could go many different ways at many points in the struggle..

Helpful Hint:  Avoid any unwanted spoiler alerts by NOT reading any of Shakespeare's plays while in the middle of watching season 1.  :-)

Having said that, if you are watching this just for the King/Queen aspect, you are good to go. I agree with others that it ended kind of abruptly, but the whole series was kind of abrupt, to me.

Again, not vast knowledge of historical accuracy, but for me the costuming and every other thing visual seemed so deeply developed, elaborate, engaging. If there is another miniseries to pick up where this one left off, done by same writers/crew, I'd gladly watch it!

There is quite a lot of explicit sex, but oddly, though I usually think that stuff is kind of gratuitous, in this it works because they don't exploit it. Evidently, there was less privacy for Kings and Queens. Plus, the sex, childbirth and head chopping, horrible war all bring to life what a physically punishing life these people led. The costumes are fabulous as are the sets. The script is wonderful, it's always easy to keep track of the story.

I went into this series expecting to be disappointed since many period dramas have low budgets for costumes, sets and scripts. I was pleasantly surprised by the quality and professionalism of this one. Even though The White Queen isn't technically a historical drama, a lot of the characters were real people in the history of the Royal lineage. Many facts have been rearranged by the script's poetic license but you still get a feel of realism throughout the storylines of each of the families at court. If you enjoy the romantic versions of period pieces and don't mind a little nudity and violence, you will enjoy this series!

This series follows the books of Phillipa Gregory.  They have been very popular reads but I have not read them as yet.  I do not know how closely they resemble the books.  I am more into history and this series has a strong enough line of history in it that when it strays from the historical aspects that it is forgivable and even enticing (it is fiction).  I could have gone with a few less sex scenes and it has a few lulls in it but not enough to lose my interest.
I will keep this in my library to be reviewed later on (I rarely review movies).  I hope to see a sequel.

This ten episode miniseries is based upon three of Philippa Gregory's best selling historical fiction novels, "The White Queen", "The Red Queen, and "The Kingmaker's Daughter (The Cousins' War)". The cast is simply terrific, giving outstanding performances, overall, and the production values are excellent. As this is historical fiction, and not a documentary, one should expect there to be historical inaccuracies and one will not be disappointed. It is historically  accurate in terms of big picture type, main events, but from there it somewhat digresses. Nonetheless, it provides a gripping storyline that will have the viewer riveted to the screen.

This miniseries covers the reigns of Kings Edward IV and Richard III of England. It also covers the ascension to the English throne of Henry Tudor. It focuses on three women who were to have some influence. First, there is the beautiful Lancastrian widow and commoner, Elizabeth Woodville, who would secretly marry King Edward IV of the House of York. Then there is wealthy Margaret Beaufort, the religious fanatic who would stop at nothing to make her exiled  son, Henry Tudor of the House of Lancaster, King of England. Last but not least is Anne Neville, obedient daughter of Warwick, known as the Kingmaker for his success in making his cousin,  Edward IV,  King of England. She would first marry Edward of Westminster, only son of the deposed mad King of England, Henry VI, and Margaret of Anjou. Widowed,  she would later marry Richard, youngest brother of King Edward IV, who would later become King Richard III.

While some of the machinations of these women may strain credulity, it makes for a very entertaining television miniseries. Some of these machinations are  based on historical fact, while some are not. This why it is historical fiction, with the operative word  being "fiction". There is some nudity, which is gratuitous for the most part, but it is fairly minimal given the fact that this is a ten part miniseries. Those with an interest in this period of English history, or who simply enjoy interesting, well done  historical fiction, will love this miniseries.

This is an excellent series and features a very intelligent script matched with fine dramatic performances. It effectively explores the role of women in in a complicated period of English history, and while it may vary at times from the strict historical record, the overall effect is highly entertaining. The major production companies need to keep producing such high quality period dramas, especially in series format so that character development and relationships can be fully portrayed. And the battle scenes were kept to a minimum with the emphasis being kept on story, plot and dialogue. The true test is that this series left us satisfied and yet wanting more episodes. Overall highly recommend.

I would give this 4 stars for the romance and drama, 1 star for historical accuracy. While the story involves 3 women, Elizabeth Woodville, Margaret Beaufort, and Anne Neville, the story is told largely from the point of view of Elizabeth Woodville (the White Queen). The portrayal is sympathetic to her and probably overlooks her worst qualities. In an areas where historical data is incomplete, the story diverges to alternative explanations for events, such as the disappearance of the Princes in the tower.

For persons with some general knowledge of 15th Century England, this is a highly interesting and entertaining miniseries. For those who are not, the profusion of dramatis personae, many of whom share first names, may be confusing, especially when their changing aristocrat titles are thrown in as well. Nevertheless, kudos to Philippa Gregory, upon whose books the miniseries is based, for sorting out the many persons and their even more numerous intrigues. The story is set during the Wars of the Roses  the seemingly interminable civil battles between two branches of the royal house, those of Lancaster and of York, to secure the throne of England. The Yorkists used the white rose, and the Lancastrians the red rose. Edward IV (1461-1483), the male protagonist was a Yorkist, which explains the title of the series, White Queen, even though his Queen Consort, Elizabeth, was a Lancastrian. By all accounts Edward was a tall and handsome man, and an able king who ruled effectively and who sponsored scholarship and art. Elizabeth was by most accounts one of the most beautiful women of all England. The Wars of the Roses ended when Lancastrian Henry Tudor defeated Richard III and became king Henry VII and married Elizabeth, daughter of Edward IV and Elizabeth, Yorkists. In addition to Philippa Gregorys historical novels, interested audience may well find Shakepeare fascinating and enlightening (the three parts of Henry VI and Richard III, though none centered on Edward IV).

As a fan of historical drama and a guilty anglophile, this is right up my alley. I enjoy seeing the venality of the ruling classes, the pomposity, scheming, bloodthirstiness, lying, bowdlerizing, amoral antics of those whom Creation has cursed with great wealth and good looks. I enjoy the squandering of power on the mental shoving matches as one cranberry brain after another jostles for the crown, only to descend even further into degenerate glory.

These folks wrote (and continue to write) much of world history and understanding them is important to anybody who may eventually be left to carry on with whatever remains of our maimed, screwed planet. The lessons are many. Beautiful though the trappings may be, the undercurrent of perversion is constant. Look out for oneself, and to the block with everybody else. Western Civilization at its brightest and the legacy that lingers portends a harsh reality for all who are not of the right 'House' -  (or race or color). The filming is pretty, the acting is fine, the direction well done. Battles are depicted without excess of vista, extras or SpFx, which is fine by me. Intimacy is sensually portrayed, even in its colder, unloving and soul-less moments.

We did not think we'd be interested in pre-Henry VIII, medieval English politics.  Turns out that this is both a pivotal and fascinating time in English history that far fewer are aware of but just as important.  A detailed discovery of the 30 year war between two main family branches that leads to the next era of power and ultimately connected to present day.  Well executed in production, acting, period settings and wardrobe.  A cant miss series - a Standing Ovation to Starz and the entire cast of The White Queen!

I watched all 10 episodes and did enjoy the series. It was exciting and kept my interest. However, it jumped too rapidly from one event to another. Some of the events could have been fleshed out; this would have made a longer but better series.

Rebecca Ferguson who plays Elizabeth Woodville and later Queen Elizabeth, was amazing in this series. She is a terrific actress with wonderful depth. She is also a great beauty.  Some of the others were pretty good, but she is on a level above them all. Max Irons plays Prince Edward. He certainly looks the part of a prince. His acting is not very remarkable, however. I will say he got better as he went along. By episode 6 he was much better, although no match for Rebecca Ferguson.

Unfortunately, Amanda Hale, the actress who plays Margaret Beaufort, had too big a part for her acting ability. She got somewhat better towards the end but not nearly good enough for such a big part. I found her facial expressions and gestures very irritating.

Regardless of some poor acting at times, this is a good series to watch. I debated between giving this 3 or 4 stars.

This is a beautifully portrayed journey into the confusing and harrowing time of the Cousins War...better known as the War of the Roses. All those who were engaged in these power struggles could not escape taking one side, or to survive, even both sides of their extended family feud. Everyone had relatives who had been killed. Everyone had times of danger and betrayal. The women focused on here had the most to lose. But, unlike an equally engaging civil war - The Game of Thrones - this war actually occurred wearing out all of England's resources and all of their people. Be prepared for romance, danger, a touch of magical belief, and tragedy. Enjoyed best at home on an dark windstorm day.

What I thought might be a well-rounded period drama on par with The Tudors and The Borgias (both better shows by leaps and bounds) turned out to be only a slightly more sophisticated version of a bunch of toddlers tattling on each other and throwing tantrums every time they get their way. Only the setting and the costumes are better. What all of these whining characters demonstrate is utter lack of gratitude for the fact that compared to what it was like for the peasantry of the day, they all have it really good. Each of these charecters lives in a castle, each has all the money and resources they could want, and waited on hand and foot. But nooo, they have to be the king. Game of Thrones, also inspired from the infamous War of the Roses, does spectacular job of illustrating these themes and makes for far superior entertainment to boot. As to why this show flops:

The acting is middling all around even with professionals like James Frain (far better as in the Tudors, as medieval dramas seems to be his casting niche) - mainly because all of the characters are so one dimensional. There really is no one to root for in this whole affair. Anne, mother to Henry Tudor, is a delusional, sanctimonious harpy who is worse in her plotting due to the fact that she firmly believes she is on a mission from God. James Frain and his Lancastrian cabal relentlessly pursue the throne with utter ingratitude. Initially one empathizes with the hapless Lady Jane Grey, who has everyone against her from the beginning,but as she becomes more consumed by desire for revenge she gets less likable. Her husband, King Edward, seems sympathetic enough a character if you can ignore the fact that had Lady Grey not given him what he wanted he was fully prepared to rape it out of her. It is frustrating to watch the two of them continually forgive enemies that only exploit those opportunities to plot against them all the more. Edward becomes a common debauched, cheating monarch soon enough which ruins the audience' good will toward him.

All in all, any one of the series I already named will give you far better returns on your time investment.
